column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0191] Results from the scanning procedure confirm that amplification reactions have taken place in each of the wells.
#Text=Trials conducted using known amounts of HIV-1 RNA standard are plotted on a graph, and yield standard control curves exactly as shown in FIG. 7.
#Text=The trial conducted using the test sample gives quenching ratios of about 9.5 for the WT016 molecular beacon, and about 2.0 for the WT013 molecular beacon.

#Text=These values are located on the vertical axis of the graph in FIG. 7, and the corresponding number of copies of HIV-1 polynucleotide present in the sample determined from the horizontal axis of the graph.
#Text=The test sample contains about 1000 copies of HIV-1 analyte polynucleotide.
#Text=This illustrates how quantitative probe arrays can be used in connection with polynucleotide amplification reactions to determine the amount of analyte polynucleotide present in a test sample.
#Text=[0192] In another version of the procedure, the standard control curves are highly reproducible and it is unnecessary to perform amplification reactions using standards.
#Text=Instead, the data representing the standard control curves is stored in an electronic memory device.
#Text=An amplification reaction is conducted using the test sample in accordance with the procedures described above.
#Text=Results obtained using the test sample give quenching ratios of about 9.5 for the WT016 molecular beacon, and about 2.0 for the WT013 molecular beacon.
#Text=These values are input into an entry terminal and compared electronically with the standard curve stored in the memory device.
#Text=An electronically generated output indicates the test sample contains 1000 copies of HIV-1 analyte polynucleotide.
#Text=This illustrates an embodiment of the invention wherein it is unnecessary to conduct amplification reactions using standard controls.

#Text=[0193] An alternative method for quantifying polynucleotides that relies only on comparison of the calculated ratios of signals emitted from different molecular beacons can unambiguously make such determinations without particular knowledge about absolute signal values.

#Text=This alternative method employs more than two different species of molecular beacon having binding specificity for the same polynucleotide, and relies on comparisons of a plurality of signal ratios.
#Text=This method is illustrated below.

#Text=[0194] Example 8 describes methods that were used to produce control curves that were useful for unambiguously determining the amount of template polynucleotide is a sample prior to a nucleic acid amplification reaction.

#Text=More specifically, the following procedures illustrate how results obtained using three different molecular beacons can be used for unambiguously determining starting levels of an analyte polynucleotide.
#Text=EXAMPLE 8
